results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Richard Upjohn, James Renwick, Minard Lafever, Patrick Keely: Some of the greatest  architects of New York in the early to mid-nineteenth century are represented by tour-de-force churches within a few  blocks of each other in our Brooklyn Heights SOUTH tour. Brooklyn long had a reputation as "The City of Churches", and you'll know why before we're halfway done. We'll see these and other masterpieces of the Romanesque, Renaissance, Gothic, and Greek revivals in marble and brownstone among the literally hundreds of pre-Civil War homes in this marvelous neighborhood. Besides that, hear about the great vision of the canny merchant who created New York's first suburb by grasping the significance of a breakthrough in technology; see where the clubhouse of one of the first baseball teams still stands; learn how the shocking plan to destroy this now-landmarked neighborhood was foiled; and relive the night George Washington executed one of the most daring retreats in military history after the nightmarish Battle of Long Island, masterminded in a mansion perched atop the very cliffs of Brooklyn Heights.

Where to meet: Meet in front of St. Francis College, 180 Remsen Street between Court and Clinton streets.  Take the 2,3,4,5 to "Borough Hall" or R to "Court Street". 

When to meet: 12:45am for a 1pm start. I will be holding a sign that says "Brooklyn Heights SOUTH". There are restroom facilities inside a Starbucks across the street from Borough Hall; please be sure to take a visit there if necessary before the tour starts.

Fee: $20 cash, $15 for seniors 65 + with proof of age; exact change appreciated! Please bring bills, not coins.

The tour is 2.5 hours long. For sunny days, be sure to bring a hat and a bottle of water. Check the weather reports on the day of the tour; if there is a chance of rain, please bring your own umbrella.  While Friendly Native tours usually do take place on the date and at the time they are scheduled, on occasion they will be postponed in cases of high temperatures or high probability of rain,  and an email sent out to that effect to all who have registered for the event.
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be holding a sign reading BROOKLYN HEIGHTS SOUTH
results.name: Brooklyn Heights SOUTH: Churches, War, and Real Estate!

results.description:
** This class is for anyone who is completely new to improv and have been afraid to try it out. **

** You're welcome to stay and watch the Level 2 class that's happening right after this class ends. **

Public speaking is a powerful skill to have. And there is a powerful way to build upon and enhance your public speaking presence and have a good laugh at the same time: by learning how to improvise!

Improv takes focus, a willingness to embrace the group dynamic and a commitment to fostering your sense of play.

Dewey Chaffee, a professional comedian and improvisor, will lead you through each of these areas with skill, kindness and most importantly, patience, creating an environment that is safe, comfortable, and creatively inspiring.

Improv will make you a better listener, a more open and accepting communicator in life, and a master at slinging bullshit when you need to appear more confident than you feel on the inside!

More details here: www.PlayWithDewey.com

Anyone and everyone is welcome! 

(We prefer that you sign up online, so we can get an accurate head count. If you can only pay in-person, please bring exact change.)

-----------------------------------------------

About Dewey Chaffee

Dewey has more than 20 years of improvisation experience. He spent 23 years perfecting his skills as an improv performer for the Walt Disney Company. He's also appeared on Nickelodeon Television and worked as their audience warm up guy for several seasons of TV production.

Currently, he and his husband perform a live improvised comedy drag show called "The Lady Winifred and Didi Show."

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

NOTE: This Meetup event is currently tentative. There is a cost associated with this museum, but we may be able to reduce the group rate depending on turnout. The date is tentatively set but this Meetup event will occur at some point within the next month or two.
In addition, one thing to directly address is that a large number of the exhibits are family-oriented, but a good number of you have messaged me directly mentioning that you would be willing to go so I have placed it up here for now.

Come join us for a Field Trip to the Museum of Mathematics!

ABOUT THE MUSEUM:
The National Museum of Mathematics began in response to the closing of a small museum of mathematics on Long Island, the Goudreau Museum. A group of interested parties (the “Working Group”) met in August 2008 to explore the creation of a new museum of mathematics — one that would go well beyond the Goudreau in both its scope and methodology. The group quickly discovered that there was no museum of mathematics in the United States, and yet there was incredible demand for hands-on math programming. Accomplishments to date include: opening Manhattan’s only hands-on science center, attracting hundreds of thousands of visitors; creating the popular Math Midway exhibition, which delighted over 750,000 visitors at museums throughout the United States; leading math tours in various U.S. cities; running dozens of Math Encounters and Family Fridays presentations; delivering many other programs for students, teachers, and the public to increase appreciation of mathematics; and creating the largest public outdoor demonstration of the Pythagorean Theorem ever.

results.description:
Join us for three hours of figure drawing in the heart of Union Square.

This session is open to sketchers of all levels.


What makes our sessions different? 

• We work in a large, clean, well-lit space. 

• Sketchers can concentrate because our room is quiet while the model is posing.

• (Latecomers can be seated at a break.)


• Every hour we take a break to look each others drawings (if you choose to put yours out.) This is a nonjudgmental and very valuable part of the session. 

• This is a three hour drawing session to work from a live (nude) model.  


• We start with 5 minute poses and work up to 20 minute poses by the end of the session. We take a 5 minute break every 20 minutes. 

• There are seats for everyone tables and several light weight easels. 


• Access to a sink is available for watercolor artist.

• Bring your own materials (no oil or acrylic paint and no sprays please.)

As always if you have any questions please feel free to email me. I look forward to seeing you there. 

Simon

results.description:
Our next meetup will focus on: Aesthetics.

The meetup runs as follows:


1) The moderator selects one subject for discussion and a date for the meeting. Subjects can be as ephemeral as "love," "god," and "purpose," or as grounded as "politics," "environmentalism," and "family."

2) At the meetup, people are encouraged to propose a question related to the subject. The moderator will collect all of the questions in a list. Questions may also be proposed ahead of time online on the event page.

3) The group will then vote on the questions. In the first round of voting, each individual may vote for as many questions as they like. The top three will then go to a second round, where each individual may vote just once.

4) The question with the most votes is then discussed. Often, the discussion starts with a narrowing of the question, as it can be challenging to devise a question that can possibly be answered by a small group in just a couple of hours' discussion.

Finally, please consider making a small donation to help the moderator cover subscription costs.
results.name: Let's Talk About: Aesthetics

results.description:
We opened the Island in May, and now we're heading back to GOVERNORS ISLAND on it's closing weekend for our latest BIKING WITH GUYS!

Just like last time, I'll bring some fun games to play in the main field, once we set up camp.

ITINERARY: We'll meet out in front of PIER 94 on Hudson River Greenway (55th St) at 1:00pm, on bike path in front of here:

Then we'll ride down the bike path towards the southern tip of Manhattan. For those of you running late or who live closer to downtown, we'll make a pit-stop at 1:20pm IN FRONT OF THE RESTROOMS AT CHRISTOPHER STREET PIER. We'll resume our ride down the Hudson River Park bike path til we get to Governors Island Ferry, then take the 5 minute ferry ride to the Island (don't worry, there's space for all of us and our bikes!). **The ferry costs $2.00 roundtrip.


FEE: a $5.00 minimum donation, with proceeds from this and future rides going to CYCLING FOR THE CAUSE, the annual AIDS RIDE that benefits our very own LGBT CENTER. (You may pay your tour guide Joey in cash at the event, or via FREE Venmo phone app before/day of ride)

What you need to bring:

*YOUR BIKE (if you don't have your own, you may rent one for the day at one of the numerous bike shops around the city. You will need to rent your bike before the group meets at 1:00pm, we cannot wait for you to rent your bike after start time. we may decide to change meeting point to a bike rental shop, depending on demand.)

(You should NOT get a Citibike, they require to be checked in every 30-45 minutes, and to be courteous to all the other riders we won't be stopping to swap them out all day!)

*BACKPACK/NAPSACK- to carry all of your supplies

*HELMET- Safety is very important, protect yourself!

*HOODIE or JACKET- It may get a bit brisk on our ride back or on the Island

*WATER- we all need to keep hydrated

*SNACKS/FOOD- to eat at the picnic, or pick up something along the way

*SHEET OR BLANKET- not required, but it'll be more comfortable to lie on the grass with!

*CASH and ID- if you want to pick up treats and/or drink, some places only take cash

*BIKE LOCK- If you have one, you may wish to bring it, just in case we decide to stop somewhere at end of trip and want to lock it up

***DISCLAIMER: We strongly recommend wearing a helmet for every BIKING WITH GUYS trip. If you rent a bike, helmets are usually included with the rental. Guy Social is not responsible for any possible injuries that may occur during this or any bike trip we host. This is a recreational but not beginners biking event, and you must have some solid basic bicycling skills to partake in this event. We advocate bike safety and biking rules of the road. Any injury is solely the individual's responsibility, and Guy Social or any representative of Guy Social is not liable, financially or in any other manner. By reading these terms,  submitting your RSVP, and attending the event, you understand and agree to these terms.

Author Meredith Schorr will speak about her journey that led to the publication of her four novels. Based on her experience, she’ll discuss:

How to seek agents Self-publishing considerations Signing with a small press for her first book How she found her current publisher The pros and cons of signing with a small press based on her experience

The presentation will be informal, and questions are welcome.

A born and bred New Yorker, Meredith discovered her passion for writing when she began to enjoy drafting work-related emails way more than she was probably supposed to. After trying her hand penning children’s stories and blogging her personal experiences, Meredith found her calling writing chick lit and contemporary women’s fiction.

She secures much inspiration from her day job as a hard-working trademark paralegal and her still single (but looking) status. Meredith is also the co-founder of BookBuzz, a live author/reader event held annually. She is a loyal New York Yankees fan and an avid runner. Meredith is the author of four novels published with Booktrope Editions and AmazonEncore. To learn more, visit her at <a>www.meredithschorr.com.</a>

results.description:
While Eisenstein documented the forces of totalitarianism and Stalinism upon the faces of the Russian peoples, DeLillo offers a stunning, at times overwhelming, document of the twin forces of the Cold War and American culture, compelling that "swerve from evenness" in which he finds events and people both wondrous and horrifying.

Underworld opens with a breathlessly graceful prologue set during the final game of the Giants-Dodgers pennant race in 1951. Written in what DeLillo calls "super-omniscience" the sentences sweep from young Cotter Martin as he jumps the gate to the press box, soars over the radio waves, runs out to the diamond, slides in on a fast ball, pops into the stands where J. Edgar Hoover is sitting with a drunken Jackie Gleason and a splenetic Frank Sinatra, and learns of the Soviet Union's second detonation of a nuclear bomb. It's an absolutely thrilling literary moment. When Bobby Thomson hits Branca's pitch into the outstretched hand of Cotter—the "shot heard around the world"—and Jackie Gleason pukes on Sinatra's shoes, the events of the next few decades are set in motion, all threaded together by the baseball as it passes from hand to hand.

"It's all falling indelibly into the past," writes DeLillo, a past that he carefully recalls and reconstructs with acute grace. Jump from Giants Stadium to the Nevada desert in 1992, where Nick Shay, who now owns the baseball, reunites with the artist Kara Sax. They had been brief and unlikely lovers 40 years before, and it is largely through the events, spinoffs, and coincidental encounters of their pasts that DeLillo filters the Cold War experience. He believes that "global events may alter how we live in the smallest ways," and as the book steps back in time to 1951, over the following 800-odd pages, we see just how those events alter lives. This reverse narrative allows the author to strip away the detritus of history and pop culture until we get to the story's pure elements: the bomb, the baseball, and the Bronx. In an epilogue as breathless and stunning as the prologue, DeLillo fast-forwards to a near future in which ruthless capitalism, the Internet, and a new, hushed faith have replaced the Cold War's blend of dread and euphoria.

Through fragments and interlaced stories—including those of highway killers, artists, celebrities, conspiracists, gangsters, nuns, and sundry others—DeLillo creates a fragile web of connected experience, a communal Zeitgeist that encompasses the messy whole of five decades of American life, wonderfully distilled.
results.name: September --  Underworld by Don DeLillo

** Saturday Afternoon Open Play/Clinic Combos**

We now offer, Beginner, Intermediate and occasionally Advanced, Saturday afternoon Combined Open Play/Clinics for the UNBELIEVABLE PRICE of $14.00 for a 3 hr. Session!

An Open Play/Clinic! What’s that?........It is our unique creation! Three hours of Open Play and Clinic combined! Here’s how it works. 3 teams of 8 players each alternate playing games on one of our 2 main courts at Brandeis H.S. (84th st. bet Columbus & Amsterdam) Now get this, while the third team is out, instead of sitting around, that team gets a clinic (8 players to one coach) on our back court at Brandeis with a top instructor. When the two teams finish their game on the main court, one comes off for instruction. Meanwhile, the players that just received instruction take what they just learned and use it in the next game. This rotation continues for 3 hrs! It is a great way to meet new players and improve your skills at the same time.  It is an absolutely unbelievable deal!

***Please note- RSVP'g on Meetup will not reserve your spot. Please go to our website to sign up.*** A credit card payment is required to reserve your space.

results.description:
Come enjoy a new adventure in "The Big Apple" at two of New Yorks most popular outdoor spots; The High Line and the Greenway walk and bikeway path along our beautiful Hudson River!  

Come with me by way of the Weehawken Ferry at Port Imperial, 4800 Ave. at Port Imperial Blvd, in Weehawken, NJ an 8 minute ride which is part of the adventure or if you';re driving in or taking public transportation meet us at 2:15 in front of the NYWaterway building at Pier 79  where we will exit on West 39th street, by[masked]th Ave..  

We will enter the High Line on 34th and exit at the end by Gansevoort St., head down to the Greenway and walk back thru beautiful parks along the Hudson to Pier 81 for an optional free 45 minute boat ride on the North River Lobster Co. where we can buy dinner. depending upon availability  Check them out at http://northriverlobsterco.com (there are plenty of other food options along the way) (may reverse course)


The walk will be approximately 3-6 miles at a moderate pace with lots of stops to take in all the beautiful gardens, art and architecture along the way and to experience the High Line! We will be walking on paved paths with one stairway going up to the High Line, so good walking shoes or sneakers should suffice, along with some sun protection and MANDATORY WATER and snacks. Don't forget the cameras and smartphones, for the many photo ops!

Fee for an adult ROUNDTRIP ferry ride is $19, Seniors 62 and over is $16.50 and parking on weekends at Port Imperial is $14. You can get your ROUNDTRIP Ferry ticket at the ticket window in Port Imperial or on line at http://www.nywaterway.com/PortImperialWeehawkenRoute.aspx

Carpooling suggested. 


WE WILL BE TAKING THE 2PM FERRY AND SHOULD BE BY THE FRONT OF THE NYWATERWAY BUILDING ON WEST 39TH and[masked]th Ave. at Pier 79 APPROX 2:15.  We will be taking the ferry back after dinner and should enjoy a Hudson River sunset!

PLEASE POST OR LET ME KNOW IF YOU WILL BE TAKING THE WEEHAWKEN FERRY OR MEETING US IN FRONT OF  THE NYWATERWAY BLDG. IN NY

 BRING YOUR PARKING TICKET WITH YOU as you can pay for your parking in machines at the Port Imperial building with a credit card or cash before returning to your car.  After paying, TAKE YOUR TICKET WITH YOU  you as YOU WILL NEED IT WHEN YOU EXIT THE GARAGE. 

PLEASE GIVE YOURSELF PLENTY OF EXTRA TIME FOR PARKING AND TO PURCHASE YOUR FERRY TICKET AT PORT IMPERIAL AND ALWAYS TO FIND A  PLACE YOU ARE NOT FAMILIAR WITH.  

INCLEMENT WEATHER CANCELS.  ALWAYS CHECK THE DAY OF AN EVENT FOR ANY POSSIBLE CHANGES.

DIRECTIONS TO PORT IMPERIAL WEEHAWKEN FERRY:

Route 46/Route 3 East

Rt. 46 east to Rt. 3 east to Rt. 495 east. Exit at Weehawken (last exit in NJ). At the traffic light keep right of ramp and continue through traffic light bear right. At the next light (Baldwin Ave.) make a left. Proceed over the railroad tracks and make an immediate left onto Pershing Road. Follow road to ferry terminal about 1/2 miles.

Route 80 East/Garden State Parkway North

Exit 159 for Rt. 80 east. Take Rt. 80 East to Rt. 95 north to Fort Lee/Palisades Parkway exit. Follow Bridge Plaza South six lights to end. Make a right onto Hudson Terrace to fork where it becomes River Road. Continue straight heading south for five miles to entrance of Port Imperial on left.

Garden State Parkway North/Rt. 3 East

Take Garden State Parkway to Rt. 3 east to Rt. 495 east. Exit at Weehawken (last exit in NJ). At the traffic light bear right. At the next light (Baldwin Ave.) make a left. Proceed over the railroad tracks and make an immediate left onto Pershing Road. Follow road to ferry terminal about 1/2 miles.

New Jersey Turnpike South

Take the NJ Turnpike to exit 16E. Proceed straight ahead on Rt. 495. Exit at Weehawken (last exit in NJ). At the traffic light bear right. At the next light (Baldwin Ave.) make a left. Proceed over the railroad tracks and make an immediate left onto Pershing Road. Follow road to ferry terminal about 1/2 miles.

New Jersey Turnpike North

Take the NJ Turnpike to exit 16E. Proceed straight ahead on Rt. 495. Exit at Weehawken (last exit in NJ). At the traffic light bear right. At the next light (Baldwin Ave.) make a left. Proceed over the railroad tracks and make an immediate left onto Pershing Road. Follow road to ferry terminal about 1/2 miles.

Route 4

Travel east on Rt. 4 to last exit before George Washington Bridge (Fort Lee exit). Take Bridge Plaza South six lights to end. Make a right onto Hudson Terrace to fork where it becomes River Road continue straight heading south for five miles to entrance of Port Imperial on the left.

From Palisades Parkway

Palisades Parkway to exit 1 (Englewood Cliffs/Palisades Ave). Make a left onto Palisades Ave. then right onto Hudson Terrace to fork where it becomes River Road continue straight heading south for five miles to entrance of Port Imperial on the left.

From Rt. 9 West

Make a left onto Palisades Ave then a right onto Hudson Terrace to fork where it becomes River Road continue straight heading south for five miles to entrance of Port Imperial on the left.

ALTERNATE DIRECTIONS TO AVOID LINCOLN TUNNEL CONGESTION

From Route 46 East

Take 46 East through Little Ferry. Continue East over Hackensack River Bridge through Ridgefield. Go Pass Exxon station on right and get off at Grand ave. (Exit 93). Continue straight, you will pass Young School on left and then cross Broad ave. at Stop sign make a left onto Route 5. Continue up hill heading east. Follow Rt. 5 signs. Second light turn right, go past Gulf Station then bear right at Rt. 5 sign, Palisade Ave. Get in left lane, at light make a left and follow Rt. 5 sign to River Rd. Continue south passing Target and then City Place. Port Imperial Terminal is 2.3 miles on the left.

From N.J. Turnpike

Take Exit 16E towards Secaucus. At ligth make a right, then bear left and go over the overpass. Follow signs for Union Turnpike. You will pass a cemetary on your left and continue up the hill to the traffic light. At light make a right and continue straight, Getty Station will be on your left. Continue east on 32nd St. past the 4 Star Diner. Make a left at Lukiol Station (Palisades Ave.) Stay straight on South Marignal Highway to traffic light (Blvd East) Make a left, pass the Hess station on right. 9/10th of a mile you will make a hgard right turn onto pershing Rd.at Stop sign make a right and follow Caryle Ct. to Port Imperial Blvd. Ferry Terminal is up on right.

From Route 80 East

Take the Rt. 46 95 South Exit, 1/2 mile exit exit at Rt. 46 East. See alternate from  Rt. 46 East.

From Route 3 East

Rt. 3 East, follow signs Secaucus NJ Turnpike South (service road). Get off at North Bergen exit. Paterson Plank Rd. east to Union turnpike. You will pass a cemetary on your left and continue up the hill to the traffic light. At light make a right and continue straight, Getty Station will be on your left. Continue east on 32nd St. past the 4 Star Diner. Make a left at Lukiol Station (Palisades Ave.) Stay straight on South Marignal Highway to traffic light (Blvd East) Make a left, pass the Hess station on right. 9/10th of a mile you will make a hgard right turn onto pershing Rd.at Stop sign make a right and follow Caryle Ct. to Port Imperial Blvd. Ferry Terminal is up on right.

Join New York Adventure Club on September 26th for a private tour of Lotus Garden, a members-only rooftop garden in the Upper West Side. Located on the roof of a parking garage, this beautiful, 7,000 sq ft urban oasis is maintained by 28 gardeners and other volunteers.

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE INFORMATION BELOW CAREFULLY, ESPECIALLY THE BOLD TYPE.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Thank you.

I will schedule this walk again on a weekend and possibly on a weekday.

If you have any questions for me, please contact me through my private Meetup inbox. The organizer for this Meetup event is John, who is listed on the top of the "going list" with a photograph. Thank you again.

Description: During the Gilded Age, Americans achieved wealth as never as before. In New York, the opera, the theatre, and grand parties consumed the ruling class' leisure hours. Sherry's Restaurant hosted formal horseback dinners for the New York Riding Club. Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish once threw a dinner party to honor her dog who arrived sporting a $15,000 diamond collar. Millionaires built stately and often gaudy homes in New York City. For example, the childhood home of Huguette Clark, built in 1907 by her father, William Andrews Clark, had 121 rooms, 31 baths, four art galleries, a swimming pool, and a private underground rail line to bring in coal for heating. It cost Clark $7M—that's about $162M in today's dollars—to build, but stood for only 20 years, bought by a developer after Clark's death for less than half the construction cost and demolished to make way for a wealthy apartment house at 960 Fifth Avenue.

On this walking tour, we will discuss rich people's grand mansions, wraparound terraces, extravagant weddings, lavish parties, oversized carriage houses, conspicuous leisure, costly hobbies, spacious apartments, prissy social clubs, and wealth fest.

This is a walking tour with much commentary. We'll be walking about 2 1/2 miles. We will be zigzagging around historic Carnegie Hill and the Upper East Side. There will be plenty of stopping at points of interest. If you don't like a lot of stopping, then this type of walk is not good for you. The tour lasts about 2 hours and 20 minutes.

Below was the Carnegies’ organ in the reception hall. One of the functions of the organ was an alarm clock. (Smithsonian Institute [Unidentified Photographer

Below is from The New York Times, December 28, 1905.

Cost: The cost of this event is $2 per person, which is paid at the start of the walk. This is for the organizer's Meetup preparation costs and fees.

Meeting Time/Place: The meeting time is (after lunch) at 2:00 PM. The meeting place is outside of the entrance to Barnes & Noble Bookstore at 150 East 86th Street, which is on the south side of East 86th Street between  Lexington Avenue and 3rd Avenue. Before the walk, restrooms are available in Barnes & Noble.

Transportation Options: Take the 4, 5, or 6 subway train to 86th Street and Lexington Avenue.

Finishing Time/Place: This walk will finish at about 4:35 PM on the Upper East Side near 80th Street and Fifth Avenue. If you are planning to take a subway train back, you can then get the No. 6 train at 77th Street/Lexington Avenue OR the No. 4, 5, or 6 trains at 86th Street/Lexington Avenue.

Rainy weather cancels this walk. Therefore, if it is raining, or the forecast is for rainy conditions, I will post a cancellation notice on Saturday. If I don't post a cancellation notice, I plan to be at the meeting place. If I do cancel the walk, I will also post the cancellation notice in the Discussion Board.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Thank you.

Below was one of the Payne Whitney's wedding presents, which was under construction. Payne Whitney also received a steam yacht as a wedding present. (Photo MCNY [Unidentified Photographer circa 1903])


Below are two photos of the interior of the Payne Whitney's "wedding present" house at 972 Fifth Avenue, which was designed by architect/art collector/interior designer Stanford White. (Photos MCNY [Unidentified Photographer circa 1905])

Below is from The New York Times, March 8, 1902

---------------------------------------------------------------

Located in the background was brand-new 998 Fifth Avenue , which was the first luxury apartment house on upper Fifth Avenue. (Photos Library of Congress [George Grantham Bain circa 1912])
results.name: History of Rich People during Gilded Age and Beyond - Walking Tour (Sept. 26)

group.name: NYC/NJ Walks: Explore Architecture, Art, History & Sculpture

results.description:
Come on over to Eastside Billiards for another Pool meetup! The first one of the fall season! The fun officially starts at 2pm with UNLIMITED play until 8 pm for only $20! Pay at the front desk and tell whomever is working the desk you're there for the meet up and they'll point you in our direction. All skill levels are welcome! I hope to see you there! : :----- : : ---- : : ----- : :

Basic 8-Ball rules:

To avoid confusion and debate, here are some good rules for playing 8-ball. These are not the APA league rules, They're not "Mike's Biker bar" rules, they are the BCA rules which govern most pro pool matches. -- The table is open (free choice of group) after the break, no matter which ball(s) are pocketed.
-- A scratch or other foul results in cue-ball in hand ANYWHERE on the table for the opponent.
-- Hitting one of your opponent's balls before one of your own on a shot is a foul.
-- Missing or scratching on the 8-ball is NOT loss of game if the 8-ball is still on the table.
-- The ball and pocket must be called unless the shot is obvious.
-- The number of cushions (or other balls) the ball bounces off need NOT be called.
-- The cue-ball or ANY other ball must touch a cushion or be pocketed after a shot or it's a foul.
-- The 8 ball must always be called.

results.description:
Please join us in Central Park for our Fruitluck!  Please bring only raw fruit to share with others. It's also a good idea to bring a blanket or towel to sit on. 

I will post my phone number in the comments the day before the event so you can call me if you have trouble finding us.  There's a small chance the area I have chosen will be too crowded and if so I will find another area very nearby.

If there is rain we can switch to the nearby Whole Foods Columbus Circle.

Feel free to ask me any questions if you have them. :)

We will go at least until 5 p.m. but often go as late as 8 p.m. if enough people want to stay.  It's fine to text me if you want to come later, to see if we are still there.

I notice some people tend to bring pre-cut fruit from stores, yet this is rarely good quality and is usually left untouched at our events.  While I understand that normally people bring cut up fruit to events, the fruit will hold up much better if you simply bring whole fruit and a knife if necessary.  Many fruits don't require cutting anyway such as apples, stone fruits, grapes, berries and citrus.  So simply bringing ten apples or oranges or a couple pounds of grapes is fine, as some examples.

Also, please try and only bring fully ripe fruit to our events.  If you aren't sure how to pick ripe fruit or when fruit is ripe, feel free to message me your email address and I can send you a free write up which includes information on this.
results.how_to_find_us: Take the path closest & parallel to Central Park West once you enter park. Pass by the bathrooms on the left & the tunnel on the right. Continue walking past the small bend in the road, after which we will be on the lawn on the left.
results.name: Fruitluck in Central Park

results.description:
Join the members of The NYC Political Forum (http://www.meetup.com/NYC-Politics/) for an afternoon of engaging discussions on geopolitics and international relations.

This meetup will coincide with the opening of the 70th Session of the General Assembly of the United Nations.  With a passage of its 70th anniversary, we'll take a critical look of the U.N. seven decades after its formation. More importantly, we'll discuss the types of reforms it must implement  — as well as whether it can remain viable and relevant — as it confronts many new challenges in the rapidly-changing world.


The discussion topics will include:

• What are the accomplishments and failures of the U.N. in the past 25 years?

• Is the U.N.'s role in multi- and transnational matters more crucial than ever, or has it become irrelevant and ineffective?

• What are possible alternative forums to the U.N.?  What types reforms are needed at the U.N.?


• Should the Permanent Members of the Security Council be expanded to include other large nations — especially those with the emerging economies — such as India and Brazil?

• Does the U.S. have an inherent institutional advantage in the operation of the U.N.?  For instance, does the U.N. serve as an organizational "tool" to promote the foreign policy of the U.S.?

•  Should the U.S. have a reduced role in the operation of the U.N.? (e.g., reducing its diplomatic roles or the annual funding).

We probably will not enough time to cover all of the above points -- there will be a sequel (Part II) to continue the discussions, tentatively scheduled for later this year or early next year.


---------------------------------------------------

How the RSVP works:

The RSVP window will open on Saturday, Sept 12th at noon -- it is managed this way for fairness.  The discussions are intended to be among a small group of approximately fifteen members.  In order to attend, your RSVP status must be a confirmed "YES" -- being on a wait list is not a confirmed "YES" RSVP.
results.name: The Future of the United Nations (Part I)

Join this special free LIVE online event from across the world.

With meditation and visualisation, this powerful 30 minute broadcast features beautiful sounds and music to uplift, energise and inspire.

Experience the benefit of the enhanced collective energy of meditating with other people, whilst being in the comfort of your own home or office.

Each meditation includes an introduction, followed by a time in which to meditate in whatever way is easy and natural to you.

You are then guided through a visualisation enabling you to focus on living your ideal life.

 

Participating Live:

The broadcast begins promptly at 2.00pm and finishes at 2.30pm.

***Please click to join Meditation 101 Live at the scheduled broadcast time ***

Please note that the meditation and visualisation are pre-recorded to ensure sound quality however participation with other people from across the world is live.

Meditation 101 Live works best with the following internet browsers: Internet Explorer, Chrome, Safari and Opera.

If you need any technical help connecting to Meditation 101 Live please click here.

Testimonials:

"That was absolutely amazing! I don't think I have ever fully let go and quieted my mind like that before. I feel so inspired. By the end of the session I was filled with so much love - love for myself, for others, and love coming from Source. Unconditional, pure love. Thank you." C.L.

"Instead of the 'knowledge gained', I find it appropriate to give a 5 star to 'raising my vibrations' during the meditation.... the energy of the group was Amazing and ZINGING! Thanks... " - S

"Very enlightening and a positive way for those that can't make it physically to do so remotely.""Thank you, the second section moved me the most. I had a real moment of knowing who I was, am and always be. Also, I have in the past trained in yoga and meditation but not practiced for a number of years - I felt all the beauty of it flowing connecting through my source once again aaaahhh bliss." - A.S.

"Truly inspirational, loved it, thank you ." - Anonymous

"Really loved being able to just switch on and meditate." - L.M.

"So relaxing and cleansing." - T.H.

"Awesome meditation Tracy! One of the most powerful sessions I have ever had. Wow." - G.R.

"I absolutely loved the meditation. The music was one that I truly enjoyed. Thank you so much for this. Many blessings to you." - S.

FOR DETAILS OF ALL UPCOMING 'MEDITATION 101 LIVE' SESSIONS PLEASE CLICK HERE.

A long, long time ago, in a mind far, far away, this group was conceived by a man who desired one thing and one thing only: to spread the word of Pokemon. To bring unto the fold Pokemaniacs and newbies alike and welcome them to the word of Arceus.

Like all great visionaries, this man chose to leave his creation in the hands of another, to travel onward and bring the word of Arceus to others that had not yet heard. We have strived to continue his legacy in his absence, but none can truly compare to the original.

This is why we're dragging his behind back to New York to hang with us and remind us all how awesome he is! Make sure you don't miss this meetup as our buddy and the founder of this group Matt will be back in town and chilling with us until we decide we're sick of him (read: never).

Featuring over 100+ craft brews from New York and beyond, The Village Voice is proud to present our fifth annual curated Brooklyn Pour Craft Beer Tasting Eventon Saturday, September 26th from 3:00PM – 6:00PM in a NEW location at Brooklyn Expo Center in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

Craft beer aficionados will sample the best seasonal, micro and reserve brews from breweries located in the country with a pinpointed focus on the tri-state area plus enjoy food, entertainment and more!

Buy tickets here:
http://microapp.villagevoice.com/brooklyn-pour/2015/tickets.php

results.description:
10v10 teams, 75min+ - Intermediate level up.

Arrive 10 mins early and be ready to go on time. All players must bring a white and black t-shirt. Pass the ball & have fun!
****************************************************************

LOCATION:

Lower East Side, nr East River Park. 8-10 min walk from Delancey Street F train, head east along Houston, the field is south of Houston. Map here.

Details:

1) Teams divide into equal ability - players are welcome to signup with friends.

2) No metal cleats. Turf shoes / molded cleats only. Wear proper Soccer attire.

3) Played in a fun and chill environment. Rough play, tackles, or sliding are not tolerated.


4) If no dedicated goalkeepers, all players need to rotate in goal. Full size goals.


5) If you arrive late wait until a break in the game. Inserting players in the middle of the game disrupts the flow- it's not fair to those that arrive on time.


All players must RSVP and make payment before game time, this goes toward  field permits, equipment, meetup & CC fees.

CANCELLATIONS/REFUNDS:

You'll need to update your RSVP 24 hours before the match, to receive a credit for the next game. This is so other members have a chance to take your place.


See you pitch side!

Grand FC 

By joining this group and attending events you agree to the Waiver Of Liability.

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
